sen.j: 上夜久野駅（かみやくのえき）は、京都府福知山市夜久野町平野六ッ町1284番地2にある、西日本旅客鉄道（JR西日本）山陰本線の鉄道駅。
sen.e: Kamiyakuno Station is a railroad station on the JR West Sanin Main Line located at 1284-2, Hirano Mutsu-machi, Yakuno-cho, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 六ッ町の読み方が不明です。
sen.e: Kamiyakuno Station, a railroad facility on the JR West Sanin Main Line, is located at 1284-2, Hirano Mutsu-machi, Yakuno-cho, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Kamiyakuno Station, located at 1284-2, Hirano Mutsu-machi, Yakuno-cho, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture, is a stop on the Sanin Main Line, which is operated by the West Japan Railway Company (JR West).
sen.cmt: 他の記事と表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 山陰本線京都側の京都府最後の駅。
sen.e: Looked at from the Kyoto side, it is the last station on the Sanin Main Line that is located in Kyoto Prefecture.
As seen from the Kyoto side, it's the last station within Kyoto Prefecture on the Sanin Main Line.
As seen from the Kyoto side, it's the last station within Kyoto Prefecture on the Sanin Main Line.

sen.j: 道の駅農匠の郷やくのの、最寄り駅でもある。
sen.e: It is the nearest station from Nosho no Sato Yakuno, a roadside station.
It's the station nearest to Nosho no Sato Yakuno, a roadside facility.
It's the station nearest to Nosho no Sato Yakuno, a roadside facility.

sen.j: 駅構造
sen.e: Structure of the station
The station's structure
Station layout
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 島式1面2線のプラットホームを持つ地上駅。
sen.e: Kamiyakuno Station is a ground station that has an island platform with a railroad track running on each side.
Kamiyakuno Station is a ground station having an island platform with a railroad track running on each side.
Kamiyakuno Station is a ground station having an island platform with a railroad track running on each side.

sen.j: 無人駅で、木造駅舎は撤去された。
sen.e: It is an unmanned station and its old wooden station office was demolished.
It's an unmanned station, and the old wooden station office that once stood there has been demolished.
It's an unmanned station, and the old wooden station office that once stood there has been demolished.

sen.j: 現在は北側の跨線橋から直接ホームに入る形になっている。
sen.e: At present, passengers enter the platform directly from a pedestrian bridge built over the railway on the north side of the station.
Today, passengers enter the platform directly from a pedestrian bridge built over the railway on the north side of the station.
Today, passengers enter the platform directly from a pedestrian bridge built over the railway on the north side of the station.

sen.j: 跨線橋の入口付近に自動券売機が設置されている。
sen.e: There is a ticket vending machine near the entrance to the bridge.
There is a ticket vending machine near the entrance to the bridge.
There is a ticket vending machine near the entrance to the bridge.

sen.j: 便所は、男女共用の汲み取り式便所。
sen.e: There is an earth toilet at the station, which is used by both men and women.
The station's floor-mounted toilet is used by both men and women.
The station's vault toilet is used by both men and women.

sen.j: 駅入口寄りの1番のりば側が一線スルーとなっているため、通過列車及び行違いを行わない停車列車は上下線とも1番のりばを通る。
sen.e: Since Track No. 1, which is on the entrance side, is used by trains that pass the station without stopping, passing trains and trains that do not meet other trains coming from the opposite direction at the station pass through Track No. 1 on both inbound and outbound lines.

Because track No. 1, on the entrance side, is used by trains that pass the station without stopping, passing trains and trains that don't meet other trains coming from the opposite direction at the station use track No. 1, regardless of whether they're inbound or outbound lines.

Because track No. 1, on the entrance side, is used by trains that pass the station without stopping, passing trains and trains that don't meet other trains coming from the opposite direction at the station use Platform 1, regardless of whether they're inbound or outbound lines.
sen.cmt: 乗り場→Platform としました。

sen.j: 反対方向からの通過列車と行違いを行う停車列車は、上下線とも2番のりばに停車する。
sen.e: Trains that stop at the station to meet other trains coming from the opposite direction stop at Track No. 2 on both inbound and outbound lines.
Trains that stop at the station to meet other trains coming from the opposite direction stop at track No. 2 on both the inbound and outbound lines.
Trains that stop at the station to meet other trains coming from the opposite direction stop at Platform 2 on both the inbound and outbound lines.
sen.cmt: 乗り場→Platform としました。

sen.j: 停車列車同士の行違いの場合は、福知山方面行（上り）が1番のりば、城崎温泉方面行（下り）が2番のりばに入る。
sen.e: When two trains coming from opposite directions meet at the station, the one bound for Fukuchiyama (inbound train) stops at Track No. 1 and the one bound for Kinosaki Hot Springs (outbound train) at Track No. 2.

When two trains coming from opposite directions meet at the station, the one bound for Fukuchiyama (inbound train) stops at track No. 1 and the one bound for Kinosaki Hot Springs (outbound train) at track No. 2.

When two trains coming from opposite directions meet at the station, the one bound for Fukuchiyama (inbound train) stops at Platform 1 and the one bound for Kinosaki-onsen Hot Spring (outbound train) at Platform 2.
sen.cmt: 乗り場→Platform としました。

sen.j: 2006年度の1日あたりの乗車人員は約129人である。

The number of daily passengers was 129 in 2006.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 1911年（明治44年）10月25日 - 日本国有鉄道の駅として開業（福知山～和田山間の開通と同時）。
sen.e: The station opened as a Japan National Railway station (at the same time as the opening of the line running between Fukuchiyama and Wadayama).
The station opened as a Japan National Railway station concurrently with the opening of the line running between Fukuchiyama and Wadayama.
October 25, 1911: The station opened as a Japan National Railways station concurrently with the opening of the line running between Fukuchiyama and Wadayama.
sen.cmt: 日付を追加しました。Railwaysとしました。

sen.j: 客貨取扱を開始。
sen.e: Passenger and cargo services were started.
Passenger and freight services were started.
Passenger and freight services were started.

sen.j: 1971年（昭和46年）10月1日 - 貨物取扱を廃止。
sen.e: Cargo service was terminated.
Freight service was terminated.
October 1, 1971: Freight service was terminated.

sen.j: 1987年（昭和62年）4月1日 - 国鉄分割民営化により、JR西日本の駅となる。
sen.e: The station became a JR West station as a result of the split and privatization of the National Railway Company.
The station became a JR West facility as a result of the split and privatization of the National Railway Company.
April 1, 1987: The station became a JR West facility as a result of the split and privatization of the Japan National Railways.
sen.cmt: 日付を追加しました。Railwaysとしました。
